question: 跳ぶ
sourceAnswer: to: fly/soar | jump/leap/spring/bound/hop | spatter/scatter/splash/fly-(e.g.-of-sparks) | hurry/rush | flee/run-off/escape | disappear/vanish/fade/thin-out | break-off/come-off/fall-off/blow-(of-a-fuse) | be-sent-out-(of-an-order)/fly-(of-false-rumours,-catcalls,-etc.) | come-flying-(of-a-punch,-kick,-etc.) | be-missing-(of-a-page,-stitch,-etc.)/skip/jump-(e.g.-of-a-conversation)
activeAnswer: to: fly/soar | jump/leap/spring/bound/hop | spatter/scatter/splash/fly-(e.g.-of-sparks) | hurry/rush | flee/run-off/escape | disappear/vanish/fade/thin-out | break-off/come-off/fall-off/blow-(of-a-fuse) | be-sent-out-(of-an-order)/fly-(of-false-rumours,-catcalls,-etc.) | come-flying-(of-a-punch,-kick,-etc.) | be-missing-(of-a-page,-stitch,-etc.)/skip/jump-(e.g.-of-a-conversation)
sourceMnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>hop</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to hop</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to jump</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to leap</vocabulary>. Basically anything that gets both feet off the ground via your own foot propulsion.
sourceReadingMnemonic: Know how <ja>飛ぶ</ja> means "to fly"? This is a similar idea, though this time you're not flying nearly as much, because you're just hopping or jumping. Anyways, the readings are the same.
